   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with signs of urosepsis with
   atrial tachycardia/AFib presenting for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube
   appears to be properly functioning and is no longer an active issue.
   His urine has grown out <[**2112**] GNR
s, so unlikely a true infection and
   no longer and active issue. He also has sputum with Pseudomonas,
   currently being treated, which likely is a true infection. In his
   workup at this hospital it was learned that he has a cirrhotic liver,
   with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth muscle, and elevated IgG, and had
   significant ascites that has been 9L tapped, and now s/p a second tap
   to assess for resolution. Current active issues are the
   etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis, managing the
   arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in sinus),
   managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy), and
   managing his trach/vent dependence, Pseudomonas pneumonia, and now most
   currently, a positive UA with eosinophils and CT chest showing
   loculated effusions.
   1. Liver failure: Patient was found to have cirrhosis and ascites on
   imaging.  He had a paracentesis a couple days ago and 9L was removed
   and had a second [**Doctor First Name **] yesterday to assess for resolution, which showed
   less PMN's. Cx's from last [**Doctor First Name **] and Gstain from yesterday's [**Doctor First Name **] have
   been negative. Also with positive [**Doctor First Name **], positive anti-smooth muscle Ab
   and elevated IgG, consistent with autoimmune hepatitis etiology. Pt
   received some albumin with [**Doctor First Name **] yesterday.
   - F/u albumin this morning to calculate SAAG, but according to albumin
   from 4 days ago, would have SAAG <1.1 (0.5), differential including:
   peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, pancreatitis, vasculitides,
   hypoalbumin states, bowel obstruction, post-operative lymph leak
   note, pt received albumin yesterday after [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] this mornings add-on
   albumin will reflect this and his calculated SAAG using this will not
   be correct.
   - Added on amylase and lipase to this am's labs
   - F/u Cx's from most recent [**First Name3 (LF) **] yesterday
   - F/u with Hepatology today
   - Invite Hepatology to family meeting tomorrow at Wednesday 2pm
   2. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus. Have consulted Cards who rec an
   Amiodarone load then maintenance, which the pt was on in the past and
   stopped due to liver/lung issues. We have elected not to restart the
   Amiodarone due to this history of issues, but have started him on Dig
   instead.
   - Dig level is not elevated, will continue dosage as is.
   - Will get Dig level tomorrow morning
   - Received some IV Labatelol yesterday
   3. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to [**Name (NI) **]
   - Pt was on Cefepime/[**Name (NI) **], but yesterday d/c'd [**Name (NI) **]
   - Today is day 6 of Cefepime of 15 day course
   4. Fluid status--CXR with mild-mod pulm edema yesterday
   - Currently on Lasix gtt, will continue, now at 15mg / hr with goals
   150 cc/hr and 1-2L off per day.
   - Still about 5L positive today through LOS, but this may not reflect
   the 9L taken off during first [**Name (NI) **].
   5. Positive UA--Yesterday. On admission, concern for urosepsis but UCx
   only grow out <[**2112**] GNR's. Now with UA conerning for infxn yesterday,
   and have sent off UCx this am. Having low grade 100 temps for a couple
   days. WBC's at 9
   - F/u UCx.
   - Continues on Cefepime.
   - Hold off on starting new ABx for now but will consider broadening if
   urine Cx grows out
   6. Loculated pleural effusions, R > L.
   - Unsure what to do with this result in face of overall goals of care.
   Will be addressed at family meeting today whether to be aggressive with
   this or not.
   - Will need f/u of final CT read
   - Consult IP about draining them today, and if we proceed, will need to
   have Argatroban stopped for procedure.
   7. UA with persistent eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial
   nephritis, in setting of persistently elevated Cr. DDx includes
   allergic rxn to drugs, infxns including pyelonephritis, and
   infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma, leukemia.
   - Renal consult this am about eosinophilia.
   - Consider CT abdomen to assess for pyelonephritis, although was not
   seen on last CT abdomen/pelvis done recently
   8. Drifting down Hct: Has been slowly going down through admission and
   likely a consequence of phlebotomizing with q4 coag checks due to
   argatroban. No obvious source of bleeding and no hemodynamic changes.
   Had iron studies this admission showing low level iron and labs
   consistent with anemia of chronic disease. Also, had hematuria on most
   recent UA, but urine is clear and blood loss in urine unlikely to be
   hemodynamically relevant, but will need to watch and consider if
   continued drop in Hct.
   - As PTT is stabilizing, can space q4 coags to q6 and if continued
   stable PTT, likely just [**Hospital1 **]
   - Guiac all stools
   - Watch vitals signs
   - Will get pm Hct
   - Has triple lumen subclavian and L PIV
   - Type and screen this morning, transfuse for <21
   9. Persistent respiratory failure: Reportedly on vent for the last 6
   mos.  Failure to wean could be both pneumonia as well as component of
   weakness, echo findings of RV dysfunction suggesting possible PE
   (unable to anticoagulate d/t persistent GI bleed) or pulmonary HTN, or
   persistent pleural effusions due to persistent ascites.
   - Had SBT yesterday but got tachy and sweaty after several hours so put
   back on PS 8/5
   - Had good RSBI this morning at 74
   - Will have SBT with Passy Muir valve this morning
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well
   10. H/o HIT with need to be anticoagulated. LENI's are negative
   - Started on Argatroban gtt for PE prophylaxis per Heme recs with goal
   PTT 40-60
   - Currently within range at 0.2 mcg/kg/hr with PTT 50 so will continue
   as is
   11. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Back up this
   morning to 147
   - Will increase free water via G tube to 300 q4hrs, but is a delicate
   balance between lowering pt
s hypernatremia and trying to get fluids
   off him with Lasix gtt
   - Measure pm Na
   12. Hypotension: The patient was hypotensive with poor urine output on
   admission, and thought to be distributive shock from urosepsis or PNA
   and started on ABx. Was started on pressors which have now been weaned.
   No longer an active issue
   - Watch hemodynamics through the day
   - Control tachycardia as above with BBlockade, as tolerated by bp
   - Cefipime for Pulm (pseudomonas) infectious sources
   - NS bolus to improve urine output prn
   13. Acute on Chronic Renal failure: Likely a chronic renal
   insufficiency with Cr
s in the 2
s on admission. Lasix diuresis at OSH
   was also limited by renal failure. Of note, UA came back positive for
   urine eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial nephritis.
   - Renal consult in setting of positive urine eosinophils concerning for
   AIN.
   - Cr is chronically elevated, but will continue to trend.  Is 2.4 this
   morning, within recent baseline.
   - renally dose meds
   - Watch UOP through today
   11. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   -increase dose of seroquel today if needed.
   12. S/P CABG: Elevated troponins likely rate/renal function related.
   - ASA
   - Statin has been d/c
   13. Depression:
   - Continue Paxil
   14. "Funny Carotids" No signs of stroke, neuro exam WNL. Not an active
   issue.
   - carotid dopplers with <40% stenosis
   - not active issue
   15. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   16. G-tube malfunction: functioning per surgery, Radiology and nursing.
   Surgery has signed off. Not an active issue
   FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, systemic Argatroban
   Access: L subclavian triple lumen. R art line, L PIV. Will need to have
   PICC placed, likely today, and can d/c subclavian line after that.
   Code:  DNR, already tracheally intubated.
   Communication: Patient, daughter [**Name (NI) **]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11465**] (home); cell:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11466**]
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement --> Have set up a family
   meeting for Wednesday at 2pm with daughter and will need to discuss
   goals of care.

s, so unlikely a true infection and

   currently being treated, which likely is a true infection. In his
   workup at this hospital it was learned that he has a cirrhotic liver,
   with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth muscle, and elevated IgG, and had
   significant ascites that has been 9L tapped, and now s/p a second tap
   to assess for resolution. Current active issues are the
   etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis, managing the
   arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in sinus),
   managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy), and
   managing his trach/vent dependence, Pseudomonas pneumonia, and now most
   currently, a positive UA with eosinophils and CT chest showing
   loculated effusions.
   1. Liver failure: Patient was found to have cirrhosis and ascites on
   imaging.  He had a paracentesis a couple days ago and 9L was removed
   and had a second [**Doctor First Name **] yesterday to assess for resolution, which showed
   less PMN's. Cx's from last [**Doctor First Name **] and Gstain from yesterday's [**Doctor First Name **] have
   been negative. Also with positive [**Doctor First Name **], positive anti-smooth muscle Ab
   and elevated IgG, consistent with autoimmune hepatitis etiology. Pt
   received some albumin with [**Doctor First Name **] yesterday.
   - F/u albumin this morning to calculate SAAG, but according to albumin
   from 4 days ago, would have SAAG <1.1 (0.5), differential including:
   peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, pancreatitis, vasculitides,
   hypoalbumin states, bowel obstruction, post-operative lymph leak
   note, pt received albumin yesterday after [**Last Name (LF) **], [**First Name3 (LF) **] this mornings add-on
   albumin will reflect this and his calculated SAAG using this will not
   be correct.
   - Added on amylase and lipase to this am's labs
   - F/u Cx's from most recent [**First Name3 (LF) **] yesterday
   - F/u with Hepatology today
   - Invite Hepatology to family meeting tomorrow at Wednesday 2pm
   2. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus. Have consulted Cards who rec an
   Amiodarone load then maintenance, which the pt was on in the past and
   stopped due to liver/lung issues. We have elected not to restart the
   Amiodarone due to this history of issues, but have started him on Dig
   instead.
   - Dig level is not elevated, will continue dosage as is.
   - Will get Dig level tomorrow morning
   - Received some IV Labatelol yesterday
   3. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to [**Name (NI) **]
   - Pt was on Cefepime/[**Name (NI) **], but yesterday d/c'd [**Name (NI) **]
   - Today is day 6 of Cefepime of 15 day course
   4. Fluid status--CXR with mild-mod pulm edema yesterday
   - Currently on Lasix gtt, will continue, now at 15mg / hr with goals
   150 cc/hr and 1-2L off per day.
   - Still about 5L positive today through LOS, but this may not reflect
   the 9L taken off during first [**Name (NI) **].
   5. Positive UA--Yesterday. On admission, concern for urosepsis but UCx
   only grow out <[**2112**] GNR's. Now with UA conerning for infxn yesterday,
   and have sent off UCx this am. Having low grade 100 temps for a couple
   days. WBC's at 9
   - F/u UCx.
   - Continues on Cefepime.
   - Hold off on starting new ABx for now but will consider broadening if
   urine Cx grows out
   6. Loculated pleural effusions, R > L.
   - Unsure what to do with this result in face of overall goals of care.
   Will be addressed at family meeting today whether to be aggressive with
   this or not.
   - Will need f/u of final CT read
   - Consult IP about draining them today, and if we proceed, will need to
   have Argatroban stopped for procedure.
   7. UA with persistent eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial
   nephritis, in setting of persistently elevated Cr. DDx includes
   allergic rxn to drugs, infxns including pyelonephritis, and
   infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma, leukemia.
   - Renal consult this am about eosinophilia.
   - Consider CT abdomen to assess for pyelonephritis, although was not
   seen on last CT abdomen/pelvis done recently
   8. Drifting down Hct: Has been slowly going down through admission and
   likely a consequence of phlebotomizing with q4 coag checks due to
   argatroban. No obvious source of bleeding and no hemodynamic changes.
   Had iron studies this admission showing low level iron and labs
   consistent with anemia of chronic disease. Also, had hematuria on most
   recent UA, but urine is clear and blood loss in urine unlikely to be
   hemodynamically relevant, but will need to watch and consider if
   continued drop in Hct.
   - As PTT is stabilizing, can space q4 coags to q6 and if continued
   stable PTT, likely just [**Hospital1 **]
   - Guiac all stools
   - Watch vitals signs
   - Will get pm Hct
   - Has triple lumen subclavian and L PIV
   - Type and screen this morning, transfuse for <21
   9. Persistent respiratory failure: Reportedly on vent for the last 6
   mos.  Failure to wean could be both pneumonia as well as component of
   weakness, echo findings of RV dysfunction suggesting possible PE
   (unable to anticoagulate d/t persistent GI bleed) or pulmonary HTN, or
   persistent pleural effusions due to persistent ascites.
   - Had SBT yesterday but got tachy and sweaty after several hours so put
   back on PS 8/5
   - Had good RSBI this morning at 74
   - Will have SBT with Passy Muir valve this morning
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well
   10. H/o HIT with need to be anticoagulated. LENI's are negative
   - Started on Argatroban gtt for PE prophylaxis per Heme recs with goal
   PTT 40-60
   - Currently within range at 0.2 mcg/kg/hr with PTT 50 so will continue
   as is
   11. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Back up this
   morning to 147
   - Will increase free water via G tube to 300 q4hrs, but is a delicate
   balance between lowering pt
s hypernatremia and trying to get fluids
   off him with Lasix gtt
   - Measure pm Na
   12. Hypotension: The patient was hypotensive with poor urine output on
   admission, and thought to be distributive shock from urosepsis or PNA
   and started on ABx. Was started on pressors which have now been weaned.
   No longer an active issue
   - Watch hemodynamics through the day
   - Control tachycardia as above with BBlockade, as tolerated by bp
   - Cefipime for Pulm (pseudomonas) infectious sources
   - NS bolus to improve urine output prn
   13. Acute on Chronic Renal failure: Likely a chronic renal
   insufficiency with Cr
s in the 2
s on admission. Lasix diuresis at OSH
   was also limited by renal failure. Of note, UA came back positive for
   urine eosinophils, concerning for acute interstitial nephritis.
   - Renal consult in setting of positive urine eosinophils concerning for
   AIN.
   - Cr is chronically elevated, but will continue to trend.  Is 2.4 this
   morning, within recent baseline.
   - renally dose meds
   - Watch UOP through today
   11. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   -increase dose of seroquel today if needed.
   12. S/P CABG: Elevated troponins likely rate/renal function related.
   - ASA
   - Statin has been d/c
   13. Depression:
   - Continue Paxil
   14. "Funny Carotids" No signs of stroke, neuro exam WNL. Not an active
   issue.
   - carotid dopplers with <40% stenosis
   - not active issue
   15. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   16. G-tube malfunction: functioning per surgery, Radiology and nursing.
   Surgery has signed off. Not an active issue
   FEN: IVF as above, replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, systemic Argatroban
   Access: L subclavian triple lumen. R art line, L PIV. Will need to have
   PICC placed, likely today, and can d/c subclavian line after that.
   Code:  DNR, already tracheally intubated.
   Communication: Patient, daughter [**Name (NI) **]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11465**] (home); cell:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11466**]
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement --> Have set up a family
   meeting for Wednesday at 2pm with daughter and will need to discuss
   goals of care.<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the patient's daily progress note, I have summarized the information and identified potential medical complications that may arise:

**Summary:**

The patient is a 73-year-old male who presented with signs of urosepsis, atrial tachycardia, and cirrhosis. He has undergone various treatments, including paracentesis, antibiotics, and anticoagulation therapy. The patient's current conditions include ascites, pleural effusions, acute renal failure, and respiratory failure.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Liver Failure:** The patient has cirrhosis, and his liver function is compromised. Further deterioration could lead to hepatic encephalopathy, bleeding, or infection.
2. **Arrhythmia:** The patient's arrhythmia is currently controlled, but there is a risk of recurrence or development of new arrhythmias, especially with the use of digoxin.
3. **Pneumonia:** The patient has Pseudomonas pneumonia, which is sensitive to cefepime. However, there is a risk of development of resistance or progression to more severe disease.
4. **Acute Interstitial Nephritis:** The patient's urine culture is positive for eosinophils, which may indicate acute interstitial nephritis. This could lead to further renal impairment or failure.
5. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient is dependent on mechanical ventilation and has a history of respiratory failure. Weaning from the ventilator may be challenging, and there is a risk of respiratory arrest or pneumonia.
6. **Hypotension:** The patient has had episodes of hypotension, which could recur, especially if there is inadequate fluid resuscitation or if the patient develops distributive shock.
7. **Hypernatremia:** The patient has hypovolemic hypernatremia, which could lead to further dehydration or electrolyte imbalances if not managed properly.
8. **Renal Failure:** The patient has chronic renal insufficiency, and his creatinine levels are elevated. Further deterioration could lead to end-stage renal disease or the need for dialysis.
9. **Infection:** The patient has had multiple infections, including pneumonia and urinary tract infections. There is a risk of development of new infections or progression of existing ones.
10. **Cerebral Edema:** The patient's liver failure and ascites may increase the risk of cerebral edema, which could lead to neurological complications or death.

**Plan:**

1. Monitor the patient's liver function and adjust treatment accordingly.
2. Continue antibiotic therapy for pneumonia and urinary tract infections.
3. Manage the patient's arrhythmia with digoxin and monitor for signs of recurrence or new arrhythmias.
4. Consider renal consult for further evaluation and management of acute interstitial nephritis.
5. Wean the patient from mechanical ventilation slowly and carefully, monitoring for signs of respiratory distress or failure.
6. Manage the patient's hypotension with fluids and vasopressors as needed.
7. Monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust treatment accordingly.
8. Consider dialysis if the patient's renal function continues to deteriorate.
9. Monitor the patient for signs of infection and adjust treatment accordingly.
10. Consider consulting neurology for further evaluation and management of potential cerebral edema.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the key points as follows:

**Current Status:**

* The patient is a 73-year-old male with a history of cirrhosis, ascites, and liver failure, currently in the ICU with a tracheostomy and ventilator-dependent.
* He has a positive urine culture with eosinophils, suggesting possible acute interstitial nephritis.
* He has a history of HIT and is being anticoagulated with argatroban.
* He has a positive sputum culture with Pseudomonas, which is sensitive to Cefepime.
* He has moderate bilateral pleural effusions and loculated pleural effusions on the right side.
* He has a history of atrial fibrillation, which is currently under control.
* He has a history of depression and is being treated with Paxil.
* He has a history of "funny carotids" but no signs of stroke or neurologic deficits.

**Active Issues:**

1. **Liver Failure:** The patient has cirrhosis and ascites, and his liver function is compromised. He had a paracentesis to remove 9L of ascites and a second tap to assess for resolution, which showed less PMN's. His liver function tests are abnormal, and he is being managed with albumin infusions.
2. **Acute Interstitial Nephritis:** The patient has a positive urine culture with eosinophils, suggesting possible acute interstitial nephritis. He is being monitored closely for signs of kidney damage.
3. **Pseudomonas Pneumonia:** The patient has a positive sputum culture with Pseudomonas, which is sensitive to Cefepime. He is being treated with Cefepime and Lasix.
4. **Respiratory Failure:** The patient is ventilator-dependent and has a history of chronic respiratory failure. He had a SBT yesterday but became tachy and sweaty, so he was placed back on the ventilator.
5. **Hypernatremia:** The patient has a history of hypovolemic hypernatremia and is being managed with free water boluses via his G-tube.
6. **Loculated Pleural Effusions:** The patient has moderate bilateral pleural effusions and loculated pleural effusions on the right side. The management of this issue will be discussed at the family meeting.
7. **Renal Failure:** The patient has chronic renal insufficiency, and his creatinine levels are elevated. He is being managed with Lasix and other medications to control his renal function.

**Plan:**

* Continue to monitor the patient's liver function and kidney function closely.
* Continue to treat the patient's Pseudomonas pneumonia with Cefepime and Lasix.
* Monitor the patient's respiratory status and adjust his ventilation settings as needed.
* Continue to manage the patient's hypernatremia with free water boluses via his G-tube.
* Discuss the management of the patient's loculated pleural effusions at the family meeting.
* Consider a renal consult to discuss the patient's acute interstitial nephritis and chronic renal insufficiency.
* Continue to monitor the patient's electrolyte levels and adjust his medication regimen as needed.

Based on the provided physician's daily progress note, I summarize the patient's health progress in the ICU as follows:

The patient is a 73-year-old male who was admitted to the ICU with signs of urosepsis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, and respiratory failure. He has a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, ascites, and a history of HIT, which has led to anticoagulation needs. He has also had a tracheostomy and is dependent on mechanical ventilation.

Current active issues include:

1. Etiology/workup/management plan of cirrhosis, including possible liver failure, ascites, and portal hypertension.
2. Management of atrial fibrillation, including anticoagulation and antiarrhythmic medications.
3. Management of respiratory failure, including weaning from mechanical ventilation and treatment of underlying infections, such as Pseudomonas pneumonia.
4. Management of acute on chronic renal failure, including diuresis and treatment of underlying causes, such as allergic reactions to medications.
5. Management of positive urine culture, including treatment with Cefepime and consideration of broadening antibiotic coverage.
6. Management of loculated pleural effusions, including consideration of drainage and treatment of underlying causes.
7. Anemia, including evaluation of iron stores and consideration of transfusion.
8. Hypernatremia, including management of fluid balance and electrolyte levels.
9. Hypotension, including management of blood pressure and cardiac output.
10. Agitation/delirium, including management with seroquel and consideration of other treatment options.
11. Depression, including management with Paxil and consideration of other treatment options.
12. Potential complications, including dehiscence of sternotomy wound and sepsis.

The patient has undergone various interventions, including:

1. Placement of a tracheostomy tube.
2. Insertion of a PICC line and arterial line.
3. Administration of antibiotics, including Cefepime and argatroban.
4. Management of ascites, including paracentesis and diuretic therapy.
5. Management of respiratory failure, including mechanical ventilation and non-invasive ventilation.
6. Evaluation of liver function, including measurement of liver enzymes and bilirubin levels.
7. Evaluation of kidney function, including measurement of creatinine and blood urea nitrogen levels.
8. Management of electrolyte imbalances, including potassium, sodium, and chloride levels.

The patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management by the ICU team.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old gentleman who is currently in the Intensive Care Unit (ICU) due to multiple comorbidities and complications. The patient's chief complaints include failure to wean from the ventilator and delirium.

The patient has a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, atrial fibrillation, and a history of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). He was admitted to the hospital with signs of urosepsis and was found to have a positive urine culture for <[**2112**] GNR's. He also has a tracheostomy and is dependent on the ventilator.

The patient's current active issues include:

1. Etiology/workup/management plan of cirrhosis: The patient has cirrhosis with positive anti-smooth muscle antibody and elevated IgG. He has significant ascites with 9L tapped and apparent spontaneous bacterial peritonitis (SBP).
2. Arrhythmia: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which is currently managed with digoxin.
3. Pseudomonas pneumonia: The patient has a positive culture for Pseudomonas, which is sensitive to cefepime.
4. Acute on chronic renal failure: The patient has acute kidney injury (AKI) with a high fractional excretion of sodium (FENa) and is at risk for chronic kidney disease (CKD).
5. Anemia: The patient has anemia of chronic disease, which is likely related to his underlying cirrhosis and chronic kidney disease.
6. Hypernatremia: The patient has hypovolemic hypernatremia, which is being managed with free water via a nasogastric tube.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient is dependent on the ventilator and has persistent respiratory failure, which is being managed with argatroban and non-invasive positive pressure ventilation (NIPPV).

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

1. Sepsis: The patient is at risk for sepsis due to his underlying cirrhosis, ascites, and positive urine culture.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory failure can worsen, leading to further complications such as pneumonia or acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS).
3. Cardiac complications: The patient's atrial fibrillation can worsen, leading to cardiac complications such as atrial flutter or ventricular fibrillation.
4. Renal failure: The patient's acute kidney injury can worsen, leading to chronic kidney disease or end-stage renal disease (ESRD).
5. Infections: The patient is at risk for further infections, such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections (UTIs), which can worsen his underlying condition.

Based on the patient's current condition, the following interventions are recommended:

1. Continue to manage the patient's cirrhosis and ascites with diuretics and paracentesis.
2. Continue to manage the patient's atrial fibrillation with digoxin and beta blockers.
3. Continue to manage the patient's pseudomonas pneumonia with cefepime and NIPPV.
4. Continue to manage the patient's acute kidney injury with diuretics and electrolyte replacement.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and hypernatremia closely and adjust treatment as needed.
6. Monitor the patient's respiratory status closely and adjust treatment as needed.
7. Consider consulting a nephrologist to further manage the patient's acute kidney injury and chronic kidney disease.
8. Consider consulting a cardiologist to further manage the patient's atrial fibrillation and underlying cardiac condition.

   includes allergic rxn to drugs (esp. PCNs and H2B), infxns including
   pyelonephritis, and infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma,
   leukemia.

   - Continue diuresis but give free water for hypernatremia.
   - f/u bladder pressure

   pleural effusions.  IP will do a thoracentesis today.  Patient changed

   pneumonia as well as component of weakness, echo findings of RV
   dysfunction suggesting possible PE (unable to anticoagulate d/t
   persistent GI bleed) or pulmonary HTN, or persistent pleural effusions
   due to persistent ascites.

   back on PS 8/5
   - Had good RSBI this morning at 74
   - Will have SBT with Passy Muir valve this morning
   - ABG and VBG yesterday correlated well
   #. Anemia: Has been slowly going down through admission and likely a
   consequence of phlebotomizing with q4 coag checks due to argatroban. No
   obvious source of bleeding and no hemodynamic changes. Had iron studies
   this admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia
   of chronic disease. Also, had hematuria on most recent UA, but urine is
   clear and blood loss in urine unlikely to be hemodynamically relevant,
   but will need to watch and consider if continued drop in Hct.

Based on the provided daily progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male who has been admitted to the ICU with signs of urosepsis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, and respiratory failure. The patient has a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, liver failure, acute on chronic renal failure, and a history of HIT (heparin-induced thrombocytopenia).

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation and has failed weaning attempts. The respiratory support is being continued, and a thoracentesis is planned today to assess for pleural effusions.
* Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation, which has been stabilized with digoxin. The patient's blood pressure is stable, and the PTT is stabilizing.
* Renal: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and the etiology is thought to be ATN (acute tubular necrosis) and AIN (acute interstitial nephritis) due to elevated FENa off of diuretics. The patient is being treated with diuresis and is receiving free water for hypernatremia.
* Hepatic: The patient has cirrhosis, liver failure, and ascites. The patient is being treated with anticoagulation, and the liver function tests are being monitored.
* Infections: The patient has a positive urine culture, and the infection is thought to be due to Pseudomonas. The patient is being treated with cefepime, and the sensitivities to aztreonam are being checked.
* Neurological: The patient has delirium, and the patient's mental status is being monitored. The patient is receiving seroquel, and the dose is being increased as needed.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and the patient may require further interventions, such as tracheostomy or non-invasive ventilation.
* Sepsis: The patient has a positive urine culture, and the infection is thought to be due to Pseudomonas. The patient may develop sepsis, which can lead to organ dysfunction and death.
* Renal failure: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, and the patient's renal function is being closely monitored. The patient may require further interventions, such as dialysis or hemofiltration.
* Hepatic failure: The patient has cirrhosis, liver failure, and ascites. The patient's liver function tests are being monitored, and the patient may require further interventions, such as liver transplantation.
* Cardiovascular complications: The patient has atrial fibrillation, and the patient's cardiovascular status is being closely monitored. The patient may develop cardiovascular complications, such as cardiac arrhythmias or cardiac failure.

In conclusion, the patient is a complex case with multiple medical conditions and potential complications. The patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition as follows:

1. Respiratory: The patient is on mechanical ventilation with a tracheostomy tube, and is still dependent on it. The recent CXR shows a linear opacity in the right lung and costophrenic angle opacification, indicating possible loculated effusions. The patient has Pseudomonas pneumonia, which is being treated with cefepime.
2. Cardiovascular: The patient has atrial fibrillation (AFib) and tachycardia, which is currently under control with digoxin. He has a history of HIT and is receiving anticoagulation therapy.
3. Renal: The patient has acute on chronic renal failure, with an elevated FENa and eosinophils in the urine, suggesting possible allergic reaction to antibiotics or infection. The renal team has recommended bladder pressure and renal USG to further evaluate the etiology.
4. Hepatic: The patient has cirrhosis with positive anti-smooth muscle and elevated IgG, and has ascites with 9L tapped. The liver function tests are abnormal, and the patient is at risk for liver failure.
5. Gastrointestinal: The patient has a gastrostomy tube, which appears to be functioning properly. He has been diagnosed with Pseudomonas pneumonia and is receiving antibiotic treatment.
6. Infectious: The patient has a positive urine culture with eosinophils, suggesting possible allergic reaction to antibiotics or infection. The blood culture is pending.
7. Neurological: The patient has delirium and agitation, which is being treated with seroquel.
8. Hematological: The patient has anemia, which is likely due to anemia of chronic disease.
9. Electrolytes: The patient has hypernatremia, which is being managed with diuresis and free water.
10. Wound care: The patient has a sternotomy wound, which is being monitored for dehiscence.

Potential medical complications that can arise from these conditions include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's respiratory status is critical, and further deterioration could lead to respiratory failure.
2. Cardiac arrhythmias: The patient's history of AFib and tachycardia increases the risk of cardiac arrhythmias, which could be life-threatening.
3. Renal failure: The patient's acute on chronic renal failure could progress to end-stage renal disease if not managed properly.
4. Hepatic failure: The patient's cirrhosis and abnormal liver function tests increase the risk of liver failure, which could be fatal.
5. Sepsis: The patient's positive urine culture and eosinophils in the urine suggest possible sepsis, which could lead to multi-organ dysfunction.
6. Wound complications: The patient's sternotomy wound is at risk for dehiscence, which could lead to serious complications.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia could worsen if not managed properly, leading to decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
8. Hypernatremia: The patient's hypernatremia could lead to central nervous system complications if not managed properly.

Based on these findings, the patient requires close monitoring and management to prevent these potential complications.

   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be

   Pseudomonas pneumonia Rx w/ cefepime, and a new leukocytosis.

   source.  Not on steroids, w/o clear stressor and no clinically apparent
   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with
   cefepime.  He is not being treated for MRSA or VRE, and pseudomonas has
   high rates of developing resistance.
   - pan-culture and send for c.diff.
   - CXR for possible pneumonia
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic
   clearance, so we are giving lactulose.  His positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG are all suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis.
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,
   but we will wait to check sensitivities before making that change.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.

   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.  Dig level this

   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be
   properly functioning.  Being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia based on
   sputum cultures with cefepime. In his workup at this hospital it was
   learned that he has a cirrhotic liver, with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG, and had significant ascites w/ 9L tapped and
   apparent SBP, and now s/p a second tap with improvement. Current active
   issues are the etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis,
   managing the arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in
   sinus), managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy),
   and managing his trach/vent dependence w/ diuresis and thoracocentesis,
   Pseudomonas pneumonia Rx w/ cefepime, and a new leukocytosis.
   #. Leukocytosis: Today patient had abrupt rise in WBC of unclear
   source.  Not on steroids, w/o clear stressor and no clinically apparent
   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with
   cefepime.  He is not being treated for MRSA or VRE, and pseudomonas has
   high rates of developing resistance.
   - pan-culture and send for c.diff.
   - CXR for possible pneumonia
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic
   clearance, so we are giving lactulose.  His positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG are all suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis.
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,

   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to Cipro.  Will check sensitivities to Aztreonam for possible switch.

   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with urosepsis and atrial
   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be
   properly functioning. His urine has grown out <[**2112**] GNR
s, so unlikely
   a true infection and no longer and active issue. He also has sputum
   with Pseudomonas, currently being treated, which likely is a true
   infection. In his workup at this hospital it was learned that he has a
   cirrhotic liver, with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth muscle, and elevated
   IgG, and had significant ascites w/ 9L tapped and apparent SBP, and now
   s/p a second tap to assess for resolution. Current active issues are
   the etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis, managing the
   arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in sinus),
   managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy), and
   managing his trach/vent dependence, Pseudomonas pneumonia, and now most
   currently, a positive UA with eosinophils and CT chest showing
   loculated effusions.
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be to
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,
   but we will wait to check sensitivities before making that change.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.
   - f/u hepatology recs.
   #. Acute on chronic renal failure: Seen by renal yesterday.  Thought
   etiology ATN and AIN given elevated FENa off of diuretics.  Recommended
   bladder pressure and renal USG.  UA with persistent eosinophils, DDx
   includes allergic rxn to drugs (esp. PCNs and H2B), infxns including
   pyelonephritis, and infiltrative diseases like sarcoid, lymphoma,
   leukemia.
   - if pseudomonas is aztreonam sensitive will switch from cefepime as
   that could be causing her AIN.
   - Continue diuresis but give free water for hypernatremia.
   - f/u bladder pressure
   #. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.  Dig level this
   morning is reassuring.  Will continue with current dosing.
   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to Cipro.  Will check sensitivities to Aztreonam for possible switch.
   - Today is day 7 of 15 day course of antibiotics.
   #. Persistent respiratory failure: Likely a combination of pneumonia,
   pleural effusions and fluid overload.  IP will do a thoracentesis today
   which will hopefully provide some symptomatic relief.  If the tap helps
   and the effusion is recurrent, hepatology would like us to consider a

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 73-year-old male admitted with urosepsis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, and cirrhosis. He has a history of g-tube evaluation, and his current active issues include managing the etiology/workup/management plan of his cirrhosis, managing his arrhythmia, managing his trach/vent dependence, Pseudomonas pneumonia, and now most currently, a positive UA with eosinophils and CT chest showing loculated effusions.

The patient has undergone several procedures, including thoracocentesis, which yielded 900 cc of fluid with 2+ PMNs and no organisms. He has also undergone a renal ultrasound, which showed normal kidneys. His lab results indicate acute kidney injury with elevated FENa, and his urinalysis shows persistent eosinophils.

The patient's medication list includes cefepime, lasix, and lansoprazole, and he has been started on aztreonam pending sensitivity results. He is also receiving furosemide, and his electrolyte levels are being monitored.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 98.2°F, heart rate of 81 bpm, and blood pressure of 114/61 mmHg. His respiratory rate is 26 inspirations per minute, and his oxygen saturation is 98%.

The patient's physical examination is notable for ascites, and his lab results show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin. His coagulation studies indicate a prolonged PT and PTT, and his blood cultures are pending.

The patient's diagnosis includes cirrhosis, acute kidney injury, atrial fibrillation, Pseudomonas pneumonia, and ascites. His potential complications include sepsis, respiratory failure, and hepatic encephalopathy.

In terms of potential medical complications, the patient is at risk for:

1. Sepsis: Given his positive blood cultures and urinalysis, the patient is at risk for developing sepsis.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient's chronic respiratory failure may worsen due to his Pseudomonas pneumonia and ascites.
3. Hepatic encephalopathy: The patient's cirrhosis and ascites put him at risk for developing hepatic encephalopathy.
4. Acute kidney injury: The patient's acute kidney injury may worsen due to his ongoing fluid overload and electrolyte imbalances.
5. Bleeding: The patient's prolonged PT and PTT put him at risk for bleeding, especially with invasive procedures.
6. Infection: The patient's positive blood cultures and urinalysis put him at risk for developing further infections.

In terms of management, the patient's treatment plan should focus on:

1. Managing his cirrhosis and ascites: This may involve diuretics, paracentesis, and consideration of a TIPS procedure.
2. Managing his Pseudomonas pneumonia: This may involve continuing his antibiotics and monitoring his respiratory status.
3. Managing his atrial fibrillation: This may involve continuing his anticoagulation therapy and monitoring his heart rate.
4. Managing his acute kidney injury: This may involve continuing his diuretics and monitoring his electrolyte levels.
5. Monitoring his coagulation status: This may involve monitoring his PT and PTT and adjusting his anticoagulation therapy as needed.
6. Monitoring his respiratory status: This may involve monitoring his oxygen saturation and respiratory rate and adjusting his ventilator settings as needed.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and management to prevent potential complications and improve his outcomes.

   Assessment and Plan
   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with urosepsis and atrial
   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be
   properly functioning.  Being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia based on
   sputum cultures with cefepime. In his workup at this hospital it was
   learned that he has a cirrhotic liver, with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG, and had significant ascites w/ 9L tapped and
   apparent SBP, and now s/p a second tap with improvement. Current active
   issues are the etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis,
   managing the arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in
   sinus), managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy),
   and managing his trach/vent dependence w/ diuresis and thoracocentesis,
   Pseudomonas pneumonia Rx w/ cefepime, and a new leukocytosis.
    .
   #. Leukocytosis: Today patient had abrupt rise in WBC of unclear
   source.  Not on steroids, w/o clear stressor and no clinically apparent
   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with
   cefepime.  He is not being treated for MRSA or VRE, and pseudomonas has
   high rates of developing resistance. Sent for pan culture and all has
   been NTD. WBC count improving today.
   - CTM WBC and fevers
   - Continue cefipime, consider changing abio if not improving.  Also,
   consider changing if has [**Last Name (un) 270**] to aztreonam d/t AIN
   .
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic
   clearance, so we are giving lactulose.  His positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG are all suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis.
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,
   but we will wait to check sensitivities before making that change.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.
   - liver biopsy prior to discharge to better determine etiology of liver
   failure and ? autoimmune hepatitis.
   - hepatology recommends neostigmine if remains distended
   - f/u hepatology recs.
   .
   #. Acute on chronic renal failure: Thought etiology ATN and AIN given
   elevated FENa off of diuretics.  Recommended bladder pressure and renal
   USG.  UA with persistent eosinophils, and eosinophilia on
   differential.  Renal U/S normal.
   - if pseudomonas is aztreonam sensitive will switch from cefepime as
   that could be causing her AIN.
   - Continue diuresis but give free water for hypernatremia.
   - f/u renal recs.
    .
   #. Persistent respiratory failure: Has improved with combination of
   diuresis and thoracocentesis and today is tolerating trach mask trial
   longer than previously.  If the effusion is recurrent, hepatology would
   like us to consider a TIPS procedure.   On trach mask for >24hours and
   tolerating well.
   - continue diuresis PRN
   - restarted argatroban for DVT prophylaxis.
   .
   #. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Now back up
   to 146, which may be contributing to his altered mental status.  We
   will be more aggressive in our correction, giving a 500cc D5W bolus.
   We can also resume 300cc free water flushes Q4hrs with tube feeds.
   - Give d5W to repair
   - Measure Na in aft.
   .
   #. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.    Will continue
   with current dosing.
   .
   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to Cipro.  Will check sensitivities to Aztreonam for possible switch.
   - Today is day 9 of 15 day course of antibiotics.
   .
   #. Anemia: Has a stable microcytic anemia. Had iron studies this
   admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease.  Hct improving.  Has known GI bleed
   - Continue to monitor Hct daily
   - Transfuse for <21
   .
   #. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   - Continue PRN Seroquel 25mg
   .
   #. S/P CABG: Concerned about dehiscence of sternotomy wound on CT.
   This finding was also seen on previous CT, when cardiac surgery was
   consulted.  They were not concerned.
   - continue ASA, stopped statin given elevated LFTs.
   .

   .

   Assessment and Plan
   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with urosepsis and atrial
   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be
   properly functioning.  Being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia based on
   sputum cultures with cefepime. In his workup at this hospital it was
   learned that he has a cirrhotic liver, with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG, and had significant ascites w/ 9L tapped and
   apparent SBP, and now s/p a second tap with improvement. Current active
   issues are the etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis,
   managing the arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in
   sinus), managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy),
   and managing his trach/vent dependence w/ diuresis and thoracocentesis,
   Pseudomonas pneumonia Rx w/ cefepime, and a new leukocytosis.
    .
   #. Leukocytosis: Today patient had abrupt rise in WBC of unclear
   source.  Not on steroids, w/o clear stressor and no clinically apparent
   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with
   cefepime.  He is not being treated for MRSA or VRE, and pseudomonas has
   high rates of developing resistance. Sent for pan culture and all has
   been NTD. WBC count improving today.
   - CTM WBC and fevers
   - Continue cefipime, consider changing abio if not improving.  Also,
   consider changing if has [**Last Name (un) 270**] to aztreonam d/t AIN
   .
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic
   clearance, so we are giving lactulose.  His positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG are all suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis.
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,
   but we will wait to check sensitivities before making that change.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.
   - liver biopsy prior to discharge to better determine etiology of liver
   failure and ? autoimmune hepatitis.
   - hepatology recommends neostigmine if remains distended
   - f/u hepatology recs.
   .
   #. Acute on chronic renal failure: Thought etiology ATN and AIN given
   elevated FENa off of diuretics.  Recommended bladder pressure and renal
   USG.  UA with persistent eosinophils, and eosinophilia on
   differential.  Renal U/S normal.
   - if pseudomonas is aztreonam sensitive will switch from cefepime as
   that could be causing her AIN.
   - Continue diuresis but give free water for hypernatremia.
   - f/u renal recs.
    .
   #. Persistent respiratory failure: Has improved with combination of
   diuresis and thoracocentesis and today is tolerating trach mask trial
   longer than previously.  If the effusion is recurrent, hepatology would
   like us to consider a TIPS procedure.   On trach mask for >24hours and
   tolerating well.
   - continue diuresis PRN
   - restarted argatroban for DVT prophylaxis.
   .
   #. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Now back up
   to 146, which may be contributing to his altered mental status.  We
   will be more aggressive in our correction, giving a 500cc D5W bolus.
   We can also resume 300cc free water flushes Q4hrs with tube feeds.
   - Give d5W to repair
   - Measure Na in aft.
   .
   #. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.    Will continue
   with current dosing.
   .
   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to Cipro.  Will check sensitivities to Aztreonam for possible switch.
   - Today is day 9 of 15 day course of antibiotics.
   .
   #. Anemia: Has a stable microcytic anemia. Had iron studies this
   admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease.  Hct improving.  Has known GI bleed
   - Continue to monitor Hct daily
   - Transfuse for <21
   .
   #. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   - Continue PRN Seroquel 25mg
   .
   #. S/P CABG: Concerned about dehiscence of sternotomy wound on CT.
   This finding was also seen on previous CT, when cardiac surgery was
   consulted.  They were not concerned.
   - continue ASA, stopped statin given elevated LFTs.
   .
   #. Depression: - Continue Paxil
   .
   #. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   .
   FEN: Replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, Argatroban
   Access: L PICC.  L PIV.
   Code:  DNR,
   Communication: Patient, daughter [**Name (NI) **]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11465**] (home); cell:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11466**]
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old man with a complex medical history, including cirrhosis, atrial tachycardia/atrial fibrillation, g-tube evaluation, and urosepsis. He is currently in the ICU with a diagnosis of pseudomonas pneumonia, acute renal failure, and respiratory failure. He is being treated with cefepime, and his WBC count is improving. He has a history of liver failure, and his liver function tests are abnormal. He also has a history of chronic kidney disease and is receiving diuretics.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count is increasing, and the cause is unclear. This may be due to an underlying infection or inflammation.
2. Liver Failure: The patient's liver function tests are abnormal, and he has a history of cirrhosis. This may be contributing to his altered mental status and hypernatremia.
3. Acute Renal Failure: The patient's creatinine level is increasing, and he has a history of chronic kidney disease. This may be due to ATN or AIN.
4. Respiratory Failure: The patient's respiratory status is improving, but he still requires mechanical ventilation. He has a history of respiratory failure and may be at risk for recurrent respiratory failure.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium level is high, which may be contributing to his altered mental status. This may be due to hypovolemic hypernatremia or other underlying conditions.
6. Arrhythmia: The patient has a history of atrial tachycardia/atrial fibrillation, and his current rhythm is sinus. He may be at risk for recurrent arrhythmias.
7. Pseudomonas Pneumonia: The patient has a diagnosis of pseudomonas pneumonia, and his treatment plan includes cefepime. He may be at risk for developing resistance to this antibiotic.
8. Anemia: The patient has a stable microcytic anemia, and his iron studies are consistent with anemia of chronic disease. He may be at risk for further anemia or bleeding.
9. Agitation/Delirium: The patient is experiencing agitation and delirium, which may be due to his underlying medical conditions or medications.
10. Sternal Dehiscence: The patient has a history of CABG and is at risk for sternal dehiscence, which may be contributing to his respiratory failure.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's condition is complex, and he requires close monitoring and management of his various medical conditions. He should be continued on his current treatment plan, including antibiotics for pseudomonas pneumonia and diuretics for acute renal failure. His sodium level should be closely monitored, and he should receive free water boluses to correct his hypernatremia. He should also be monitored for signs of recurrent respiratory failure and arrhythmias.

   All other blood, sputum, urine cultures are NTD
   Assessment and Plan
   A 73 year old gentleman who presented with urosepsis and atrial
   tachycardia/AFib for g-tube evaluation.  His g-tube appears to be
   properly functioning.  Being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia based on
   sputum cultures with cefepime. In his workup at this hospital it was
   learned that he has a cirrhotic liver, with positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG, and had significant ascites w/ 9L tapped and
   apparent SBP, and now s/p a second tap with improvement. Current active
   issues are the etiology/workup/management plan of this cirrhosis,
   managing the arrhythmia that he presented with (currently continues in
   sinus), managing his h/o HIT with anticoagulation needs (DVT prophy),
   and managing his trach/vent dependence w/ diuresis and thoracocentesis,
   Pseudomonas pneumonia Rx w/ cefepime, and a new leukocytosis.
    .
   #. Leukocytosis: Today patient had abrupt rise in WBC of unclear
   source.  Not on steroids, w/o clear stressor and no clinically apparent
   infectious source.  We had been treating a pseudomonas pneumonia with
   cefepime.  He is not being treated for MRSA or VRE, and pseudomonas has
   high rates of developing resistance. Sent for pan culture and all has
   been NTD. WBC count improving today.
   - CTM WBC and fevers
   - Continue cefipime, consider changing abio if not improving
   .
   #. Liver failure:  Patient
s SAAG>1.1, making differential once again
   cirrhosis vs right heart failure.  Amylase and lipase negative.  His
   altered mental status may in part be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic
   clearance, so we are giving lactulose.  His positive [**Doctor First Name **], anti smooth
   muscle, and elevated IgG are all suggestive of autoimmune hepatitis.
   - continue cefepime.  Consider changing to aztreonam because of AIN,
   but we will wait to check sensitivities before making that change.
   - given hepatohydrothorax, need to consider [**Last Name (un) 3024**] per hepatology.
   - we will consider a liver biopsy prior to discharge to better
   determine etiology of liver failure and ? autoimmune hepatitis.
   - hepatology recommends neostigmine if remains distended
   - f/u hepatology recs.
   .
   #. Acute on chronic renal failure: Thought etiology ATN and AIN given
   elevated FENa off of diuretics.  Recommended bladder pressure and renal
   USG.  UA with persistent eosinophils, and eosinophilia on
   differential.  Renal U/S normal.
   - if pseudomonas is aztreonam sensitive will switch from cefepime as
   that could be causing her AIN.
   - Continue diuresis but give free water for hypernatremia.
   - f/u renal recs.
    .
   #. Persistent respiratory failure: Has improved with combination of
   diuresis and thoracocentesis and today is tolerating trach mask trial
   longer than previously.  If the effusion is recurrent, hepatology would
   like us to consider a TIPS procedure.
   - continue diuresis
   - restart argatroban for DVT prophylaxis.
   - Continue daily SBT/trach mask trials
   .
   #. Hypernatremia: Hypovolemic hypernatremia on admission. Now back up
   to 146, which may be contributing to his altered mental status.  We
   will be more aggressive in our correction, giving a 500cc D5W bolus.
   We can also resume 300cc free water flushes Q4hrs with tube feeds.
   - Give d5W 1000ml
   - Measure pm Na
   .
   #. Arrhythmia: Per cards, pt was in Atach, Afib on admission, was given
   Adenosine and BBlocker. Now in sinus and dig loaded.  Dig level this
   morning is reassuring.  Will continue with current dosing.
   .
   #. PNA: Pseudomonas cultured, is sensitive to Cefipime, but resistant
   to Cipro.  Will check sensitivities to Aztreonam for possible switch.
   - Today is day 9 of 15 day course of antibiotics.
   .
   #. Anemia: Has a stable microcytic anemia. Had iron studies this
   admission showing low level iron and labs consistent with anemia of
   chronic disease.  Hct improving.  Has known GI bleed
   - Continue to monitor Hct daily
   - Transfuse for <21
   .
   #. Agitation / delirium: Have started seroquel and appears to be well
   tolerating
   - Continue PRN Seroquel 25mg
   .
   #. S/P CABG: Concerned about dehiscence of sternotomy wound on CT.
   This finding was also seen on previous CT, when cardiac surgery was
   consulted.  They were not concerned.
   - continue ASA, stopped statin given elevated LFTs.
   .
   #. Depression: - Continue Paxil
   .
   #. DM: ISS, no standing for now
   .
   FEN: Replete electrolytes, tube feeds (Nutren)
   Prophylaxis: Boots, PPI, Bowel reg, Argatroban
   Access: L PICC.  L PIV.
   Code:  DNR, already tracheally intubated.
   Communication: Patient, daughter [**Name (NI) **]: [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11465**] (home); cell:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 11466**]
   Disposition: ICU pending clinical improvement<|eot_id|><|start_header_id|>assistant<|end_header_id|>

Based on the provided progress note, I will summarize the patient's current status and potential medical complications:

**Current Status:**

* The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with hypoxia and altered mental status.
* He has a history of cirrhosis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, g-tube evaluation, and urosepsis.
* He is currently being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia with cefepime.
* His current active issues include managing cirrhosis, arrhythmia, anticoagulation needs, trach/vent dependence, and new leukocytosis.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

1. **Leukocytosis:** The patient's WBC count is increasing, and the source is unclear. Pseudomonas pneumonia could be contributing to the leukocytosis, and further testing is needed to determine the cause.
2. **Liver Failure:** The patient's liver function is compromised, and his altered mental status may be due to ammonia/decreased hepatic clearance. Autoimmune hepatitis is suspected, and a liver biopsy may be necessary to determine the etiology of liver failure.
3. **Acute on Chronic Renal Failure:** The patient has acute kidney injury, and his FENa is elevated. Pseudomonas pneumonia could be contributing to the renal failure, and further testing is needed to determine the cause.
4. **Persistent Respiratory Failure:** The patient has improved with diuresis and thoracocentesis, but his respiratory status is still compromised. A TIPS procedure may be necessary if the effusion recurs.
5. **Hypernatremia:** The patient's sodium levels are elevated, which may be contributing to his altered mental status. Aggressive correction is necessary to prevent further complications.
6. **Arrhythmia:** The patient's arrhythmia is currently under control, but further monitoring is necessary to ensure that it does not recur.
7. **PNA:** The patient has Pseudomonas pneumonia, which is sensitive to cefepime but resistant to ciprofloxacin. Further testing is needed to determine the sensitivity of the bacteria to other antibiotics.
8. **Anemia:** The patient has a stable microcytic anemia, and iron studies are necessary to determine the cause.
9. **Agitation/Delirium:** The patient is experiencing agitation and delirium, which may be related to his underlying medical conditions. Further testing is necessary to determine the cause and develop an appropriate treatment plan.
10. **S/P CABG:** The patient has a history of cardiac surgery, and his sternotomy wound is at risk for dehiscence. Further monitoring is necessary to ensure that the wound does not dehisce.

In conclusion, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, including leukocytosis, liver failure, acute on chronic renal failure, persistent respiratory failure, hypernatremia, arrhythmia, PNA, anemia, agitation/delirium, and S/P CABG. Further testing and monitoring are necessary to determine the cause of these complications and develop an appropriate treatment plan.

Summary:

The patient is a 73-year-old gentleman admitted to the ICU with hypoxia and altered mental status. He has a history of urosepsis, atrial tachycardia/AFib, and cirrhosis with positive anti-smooth muscle and elevated IgG. He is being treated for Pseudomonas pneumonia with cefepime and has developed a new leukocytosis. The patient's current active issues include managing his cirrhosis, arrhythmia, and trach/vent dependence, as well as his Pseudomonas pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Leukocytosis: The patient's WBC count has abruptly risen, and the source is unclear. This could be due to an underlying infection or inflammation.
2. Liver Failure: The patient's SAAG is greater than 1.1, making it difficult to determine whether the cirrhosis is causing his altered mental status or if it is due to right heart failure. He is receiving lactulose to help with ammonia clearance, and a liver biopsy is planned prior to discharge.
3. Acute on Chronic Renal Failure: The patient has elevated FENa off of diuretics, which may be indicative of ATN and AIN. A renal USG and UA with persistent eosinophils are planned.
4. Persistent Respiratory Failure: The patient has improved with diuresis and thoracocentesis, but his respiratory failure persists. A TIPS procedure may be considered if the effusion recurs.
5. Hypernatremia: The patient's sodium levels are elevated, which may be contributing to his altered mental status. A 500cc D5W bolus and free water flushes are planned to correct the hypernatremia.
6. Arrhythmia: The patient was in atrial tachycardia/AFib on admission and is currently in sinus rhythm. He is receiving digoxin and will continue with current dosing.
7. PNA: The patient's Pseudomonas pneumonia is sensitive to cefepime, but resistant to ciprofloxacin. Sensitivities to aztreonam will be checked for possible switch.
8. Anemia: The patient has a stable microcytic anemia and is being monitored daily. Transfusion may be necessary if the Hct falls below 21.
9. Agitation/Delirium: The patient is receiving seroquel and appears to be tolerating it well.
10. S/P CABG: The patient's sternotomy wound is at risk of dehiscence, and he is being monitored closely.
11. Depression: The patient is being treated with Paxil for depression.
12. DM: The patient is being managed with tube feeds and insulin therapy.

Recommendations:

1. Continue cefepime for Pseudomonas pneumonia, and consider switching to aztreonam if the patient's leukocytosis does not improve.
2. Monitor the patient's liver function and consider a liver biopsy prior to discharge.
3. Continue diuresis and thoracocentesis to manage the patient's respiratory failure.
4. Correct the patient's hypernatremia with a 500cc D5W bolus and free water flushes.
5. Continue digoxin for arrhythmia management.
6. Monitor the patient's anemia and transfuse if necessary.
7. Continue seroquel for agitation/delirium management.
8. Monitor the patient's sternotomy wound closely for signs of dehiscence.
9. Continue Paxil for depression management.
10. Manage the patient's DM with tube feeds and insulin therapy.
